UNITED MEXICAN STATES
Programmatic Environment Structural Adjustment Loan Loan Number 7136-ME elease of the Second Tranche and Partial Waiver of hree Conditions
Tranche Release Document
Introduction e
1 The Programmatic Environment Structural Adjustment Loan (EnvSAL), a I&$202.02 million fixed spread loan for the United Mexican States (Mexico), was approved by the Board on August 6, 2002. The EnvSAL was declared effective on December 17, 2002. The First Tranche of US$lOl.Ol million (minus the front end fee of 1% of the loan amount capitalized) was released on December 19,2002.
2. The EnvSAL supports the first stage of Mexico's medium-term outcome-based program to promote sustainable development. The overarching objective of the program is to balance socioeconomic development with environmental protection and improvement. The program focuses on (i) mainstreaming of environmental concerns in key sectoral development agendas, as prioritized by Mexico; and (ii) improving the effectiveness and efficiency of local environmental management processesin Mexico.
3. This operation has supported Mexico to mainstream environmental concerns in water, forestry, energy and tourism sectors through (a) the establishment of high-level and technical coordination mechanisms with other sectors, including the setting of medium-term targets to promote mainstreaming of environment in sectoral policy; and (b) the design and implementation of fiscal instruments to promote the payment of municipal water fees and investment in municipal hydraulic works and for revenue generation from the use of national marine protected areas and corresponding reinvestment in the environmental management of these areas.With respect to program objective (ii), the EnvSAL has supported (a) the creation of an enabling environment to decentralize federal environmental management functions to the State level via changes to key laws; (b) the preparation and implementation of a stepwise decentralization strategy, which includes the use of third party certification to ensure that the quality of decentralized processes is maintained; (c) the preparation and publication of decentralization plans on the part of at least 20 states; (d) the assignment of budget and targeted use of a federal grant program (PDIA) to finance capacity building in States with plan&o assume new environmental management functions; and (e) the development and implementation of a strategy to improve public access to information on Environmental pact Assessment (E ) and permit applications based on the recent passage of a key national law on the transparency of information.
4. Mexico has met all the conditions of the Env AL, with the exception of three conditions, which have been met for the most part. Partial waivers are sought for these conditions: (i) condition 1: the establishment of Intersectorial Technical Working Groups (ITWGs) in water, energy, tourism, and forestry; (ii) condition 8: ISO-9001-2000  2
certification of certain EIA review and approval, forest fire detection and control and permit-issuance functions of the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (SEMARNAT) that are to be decentralized to the state governments from SEMARNAT; and (iii) condition 11: public disclosure of processing information of certain permits. In the case of condition 1, the ITWGs have all been established and are functional. However, technically, a partial waiver is needed and warranted, since a few of the positions described in the EnvSAL have been changed. These changes, in some cases, were to ensure more appropriate representation in the ITWG than was originally envisaged during the preparation stage of the loan; in other cases,the agency in question underwent reorganization resulting in changes in the title of the post. Nevertheless, in all cases, the positions are at the same organizational level as envisaged in the EnvSAL, continue to be with the same agencies specified in the EnvSAL, and will perform the appropriate substantive functions. In the case of conditions 8 and 11, the majority of the functions related to EIA review and approval and permits described in the EnvSAL have already been certified and processing information of related permits is disclosed on public websites. The exceptions relate to forest fire detection and control (which was transferred out of SEMARNAT to the Forestry Commission (CONAFOR) ) following approval of a new Forestry Law) and non-timber reporting (Permit No. SEMARNAT-03- 005). In the case of the latter, this is likely to be delayed since the newly-appointed Undersecretary (following recent Cabinet level changes) is conducting a complete review of permitting procedures, and there is a likelihood that some permits will be combined. Therefore it makes more senseto await completion of this review, prior to embarking on certification and setting up a system to disclose these permitting procedures.
5. Based on the assessment that the objectives of the program have been met in substance and that all conditions have been met with the exception of three conditions requiring minor partial waivers, it is proposed that the Second Tranche of the EnvSAL in the amount of US$ 101.Ol million be made available to Mexico for withdrawal from the Loan Account.
II 0 Macroeconomic Framewor
6. The macroeconomic policy framework of Mexico continues to be satisfactory. continues to implement its monetary and fiscal policies in accordance with its programs and within the framework of the multi-annual program PR 2002-2006 issued in June 2002 aspart of Mexico's national development plan I I I
7 . Economic activity in Mexico is starting to show signs of recovery after a protracted stagnation over the past few years. Output fell by 0.3 percent in 2001 in response to the sharp slowdown of the U.S. economy an has since shown a modest rebound. Real GDP increased by 0.9 percent in 2002 and 1.2 percent during the first half of 2003. The weak economic growth performance has been attributed to a delayed U.S. recovery and a contraction of private investment in view of global economic uncertainties. Despite a disappointing growth performance, the Mexican economy has been able to weather the international economic downturn and emerging market turbulence over the past few years maintaining financial and price stability and access to  3
capital markets. The twelve-month inflation reached 4.0 percent by September 2003 and is most likely to fall below 4 percent by year-end, thereby attaining the monetary authorities' medium-term inflation target of 3 percent plus/minus 1 percent. Domestic interest rates came down significantly, reaching historic lows throughout the yield curve on average during the third quarter of 2003, thereby creating adequate conditions for a domestic demand recovery. A floating exchange rate regime is being maintained and even though there have been some periods of a weakening peso/dollar rate recently, such depreciation of the exchange rate is not yet showing up in inflation or inflation expectations.
8 In terms of fiscal policy, Mexico remains committed to further fiscal consolidation in order to assure medium-term fiscal sustainability and underpin market credibility. Mexico is largely meeting its increasingly low annual deficit targets, based on the traditional definition of the deficit, through the implementation of budget adjustors that reduce spending in response to unexpected revenue shortfalls. The fiscal deficit stayed within its target in 2002 at 0.65 percent of GDP (not taking into account an extraordinary budget appropriation for the liquidation of Banrural, a highly inefficient rural development bank) and is within reach for 2003 at 0.5 percent of GDP largely as a result of a high oil windfall this year. The authorities already announced a fiscal deficit target of 0.3 percent of GDP for next year's budget. As a result of increasing credibility in the authorities' monetary and fiscal policy stance, the Mexican government has been able to refinance and redeem the remainder of its outstanding Brady bonds as well as to increase the average maturity and lengthen the yield curve of domestic public debt.

Terms of references for future sectoral activities prepared by the ITWGs reflect the input from different sectors, and has resulted in higher quality products. The successful implementation of fiscal instruments for both municipal water fees and protected areas,where funds are channeled back to the sector to improve environmental management is also noteworthy. On the activities related to decentralization, an important advance has been the certification of several processesunder the anagement Sub- ecretariat of the inistry of Environment. There have been several recent Cabinet level changes in the Tourism, Energy and Environment Ministries. This has resulted in changes in Ministries' staffing and in reviews of existing programs. Nevertheless, this Program is considered to be a key program by the Mexican authorities for mainstreaming environment in sectoral policy, and as formally requested the ank to initiate preparation of the second loan envisaged under the Program.

doc.repnme: Mexico - Programmatic Environment Structural Adjustment Loan Project : Release of second tranche and partial waiver of three conditions
doc.abstracts: The Programmatic Environment Structural Adjustment Loan Project, supports the first stage of Mexico's medium-term outcome-based program to promote sustainable development, and to mainstream environmental concerns in water, forestry, energy and tourism sectors. Mexico has met all the conditions of this operation, with the exception of three conditions, which have been met for the most part. Partial waivers are sought for these conditions: a) condition 1: the establishment of Inter-sectoral Technical Working Groups (ITWGs) in water, energy, tourism, and forestry; b) condition 8: ISO-9001-2000 certification of certain environmental impact assessment (EIA) review and approval, forest fire detection and control, and permit-issuance functions of the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (SEMARNAT) that are to be decentralized to the state governments from SEMARNAT; and, c) condition 11: public disclosure of processing information of certain permits. Condition 1: the ITWGs have all been established and are functional. However, technically, a partial waiver is needed and warranted, given changes, in some cases, to ensure more appropriate representation in the ITWG than was originally envisaged during project preparation were needed, and also, because the agency in question underwent reorganization changes. Conditions 8 and 11: the majority of functions related to EIA review, approval and permits, have been certified, and processing information of related permits is disclosed on public websites. The exceptions relate to forest fire detection and control (which was transferred out of SEMARNAT to the Forestry Commission (CONAFOR) following approval of a new Forestry Law) and, non-timber reporting (Permit No. SEMARNAT-03-005). The latter is likely to be delayed, since a complete review of permitting procedures is being conducted, and seemingly, some permits will be combined. Therefore it makes more sense to await completion of this review, prior to embarking on certification, and/or disclosure of permitting procedures. Based on the assessment that the objectives of the program have been met in substance, and that all conditions have been met with the exception of three conditions requiring minor partial waivers, it is proposed that the Second Tranche be made available.
